sentences.text: General elections were held in Gabon on 26 August 2023. Incumbent president Ali Bongo ran for re-election, representing the Gabonese Democratic Party, which had ruled the country continuously since its independence from France in 1960, including 41 years under Bongo's father, Omar Bongo|Omar.

references.text: <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.africanews.com/2023/06/27/gabon-elections-to-be-held-on-august-26//|website=Africa News|date=2023-06-27|title=Gabon: elections to be held on August 26|author=Rédaction Africanews and AFP|access-date=18 July 2023|archive-date=18 July 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230718142649/https://www.africanews.com/2023/06/27/gabon-elections-to-be-held-on-august-26//|url-status=live}}</ref>

sentences.text: Bongo was declared the winner on 30 August. However, a 2023 Gabonese coup d'état|coup d'état began shortly afterward, leading to the election results being annulled.

sentences.text: 2023 Gabonese local elections|Local and 2023 Gabonese departmental elections|departmental elections were held the same day.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-06-27 |title=Gabon: élections présidentielle, législatives et locales le 26 août |url=https://www.lefigaro.fr/flash-actu/gabon-elections-presidentielle-legislatives-et-locales-le-26-aout-20230627 |access-date=2023-08-31 |website=LEFIGARO |language=fr |archive-date=30 June 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230630072613/https://www.lefigaro.fr/flash-actu/gabon-elections-presidentielle-legislatives-et-locales-le-26-aout-20230627 |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text: The previous presidential election was held on 27 August 2016. On the day after the elections, opposition leader Jean Ping declared victory and said that he was "waiting for the outgoing president to call to congratulate me," although no results had been officially announced. Only the electoral commission was legally permitted to announce results, and the Minister of the Interior, Pacôme Moubelet-Boubeya, accused Ping of "attempt[ing] to manipulate the democratic process," while Bongo said that "you must not sell the skin of the bear before you've killed him." Nevertheless, Bongo's spokesman, Alain Claude Bilie By Nzé, asserted that Bongo was ahead and would be re-elected. Official results were scheduled to be announced on 30 August, but on that date it was stated that the announcement would be delayed by a few hours. Results were finally announced on 31 August, showing a narrow victory for Bongo, who won 49.8% of the vote against 48.2% for Ping. Turnout was placed at 59.5%. The opposition's representatives on the electoral commission refused to confirm the results, and they were therefore confirmed by a vote in which the opposition members abstained. Ping's supporters maintained that the mostly complete results they had independently collected showed their candidate beating Bongo by a large margin, 59% to 38%. Notably, the official results from Haut-Ogooue Province|Haut-Ogooue (the Bongo family's native province) showed Bongo receiving 95.5% of the vote on an alleged 99.9% turnout, an improbable result sparking widespread protests. Bongo, noting that the vote was close, stressed the importance of peacefully respecting this outcome.<ref name="Fire" />

references.text: <ref>[https://www.yahoo.com/news/bongos-fate-balance-gabon-goes-polls-031021418.html Gabon opposition chief claims election victory] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170217160304/https://www.yahoo.com/news/bongos-fate-balance-gabon-goes-polls-031021418.html |date=2017-02-17 }} Agence France-Presse, 28 August 2016</ref>

sentences.text: Following the announcement of official results, protests broke out in Libreville on 31 August, with attempts made to storm the election commission's offices. Police were out in force and tried to disperse the protesters. The Parliament of Gabon|Parliament building was set on fire later in the day. The following day, Ping claimed that the presidential guard had bombed his party's headquarters, killing two people. By 2 September at least five people had been killed in the capital and 1,000 more had been arrested. The United Nations expressed "deep concern" about the violence. Along with France and the United States, it called for de-escalation on both sides of the dispute and pressed for more transparent detail on the vote outcome.

sentences.text: On 12 December 2022, the entire Gabonese opposition gathered in Libreville for the start of a series of meetings in view of the 2023 presidential and legislative elections. This meeting, at the call of the National Union (Gabon)|National Union, brought together fifty parties, including civil society leaders. The meeting was meant to put pressure on the government to reform the electoral process, and remind the public authorities of the need for consultation with the opposition. For Paulette Missambo, president of National Union, urgent reforms were needed in order to ensure a fair election.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |date=2022-12-13 |title=Gabon: l'opposition se met en ordre de marche pour des élections « sincères » en 2023 |url=https://www.rfi.fr/fr/afrique/20221213-gabon-l-opposition-se-met-en-ordre-de-marche-pour-des-%C3%A9lections-sinc%C3%A8res-en-2023 |access-date=2022-12-22 |website=RFI |language=fr |archive-date=22 December 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221222003602/https://www.rfi.fr/fr/afrique/20221213-gabon-l-opposition-se-met-en-ordre-de-marche-pour-des-%C3%A9lections-sinc%C3%A8res-en-2023 |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text: The President of Gabon is elected for a five-year term (reduced from seven years in April 2023) in a single round of voting by Plurality voting system|plurality; whichever candidate places first is deemed elected, regardless of whether the candidate secured an absolute majority of votes. This system is thought to be a disadvantage to the fractious opposition, which would appear to have little chance of winning unless it unites behind a single candidate.

sentences.text: The 143 members of the National Assembly are elected from single-member constituencies using the two-round system.

references.text: <ref>[http://www.gabonactu.com/communique-final-du-conseil-des-ministres-du-26-janvier-2018-tout-le-texte-decoupage-electoral/ Communiqué final du conseil des ministres du 26 janvier 2018 (Tout le texte + découpage électoral)] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180809004651/http://www.gabonactu.com/communique-final-du-conseil-des-ministres-du-26-janvier-2018-tout-le-texte-decoupage-electoral/ |date=9 August 2018 }} Gabon Actu, 26 January 2018</ref>

sentences.text: The elections were held using double simultaneous vote system, with voters casting a single ballot for their preferred candidate for president and National Assembly.

Jean Ping, the former Chairperson of the African Union Commission|chair of the African Union Commission who received 48% of the vote in the 2016 Gabonese presidential election|2016 presidential election, declined to stand, saying "I cannot be a candidate in an election that is a foregone conclusion".

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |author=Yves Laurent Goma |date=2023-08-18 |title=Gabon: Albert Ondo Ossa, candidat unique et "consensuel" de l'opposition pour la présidentielle |url=https://www.rfi.fr/fr/afrique/20230818-gabon-albert-ondo-ossa-candidat-unique-et-consensuel-de-l-opposition-pour-la-pr%C3%A9sidentielle |publisher=Radio France internationale |access-date=23 August 2023 |archive-date=24 August 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230824090738/https://www.rfi.fr/fr/afrique/20230818-gabon-albert-ondo-ossa-candidat-unique-et-consensuel-de-l-opposition-pour-la-pr%C3%A9sidentielle |url-status=live }}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-07-13 |title=L'Entretien - Jean Ping : "Je ne peux pas être candidat à une élection qui est pipée d'avance" |url=https://www.france24.com/fr/%C3%A9missions/l-entretien/20230713-jean-ping-je-ne-peux-pas-%C3%AAtre-candidat-%C3%A0-une-%C3%A9lection-qui-est-pip%C3%A9e-d-avance |access-date=2023-08-31 |website=France 24 |language=fr |archive-date=31 August 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230831111205/https://www.france24.com/fr/%C3%A9missions/l-entretien/20230713-jean-ping-je-ne-peux-pas-%C3%AAtre-candidat-%C3%A0-une-%C3%A9lection-qui-est-pip%C3%A9e-d-avance |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text: The government announced the indefinite restriction of internet access and a nightly curfew on the evening of the election following the end of voting. The same day, the government suspended broadcasts of French media channels France 24, Radio France Internationale|RFI, and TV5Monde.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |last=Tasamba |first=James |date=2023-08-29 |title=Internet blackout continues in Gabon amid delays in release of election results |url=https://www.aa.com.tr/en/africa/internet-blackout-continues-in-gabon-amid-delays-in-release-of-election-results/2978061 |access-date=2023-08-29 |website=Anadolu Agency |archive-date=29 August 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230829155322/https://www.aa.com.tr/en/africa/internet-blackout-continues-in-gabon-amid-delays-in-release-of-election-results/2978061 |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text: According to Michel Stephane Bonda, head of the Gabonese Elections Centre, on state television, Bongo defeated his major competitor Albert Ondo Ossa, who received 30.77 percent of the vote, in a single round of voting, while 12 other candidates split the remaining votes. The voter turnout was 56.65%.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-08-30 |title=Ali Bongo Re-elected As President Of Gabon: Official Results |url=https://www.barrons.com/news/ali-bongo-re-elected-as-president-of-gabon-official-results-9cddf976 |access-date=2023-08-30 |website=Barrons |language=en |archive-date=30 August 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230830083737/https://www.barrons.com/news/ali-bongo-re-elected-as-president-of-gabon-official-results-9cddf976 |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text: The results of the elections for the Parliament of Gabon were unclear following the 2023 Gabonese coup d'état|coup d'état four days after the general election.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite news |last=Beaumont |first=Peter |date=2023-08-30 |title=Gabon military officers declare coup after Ali Bongo wins disputed election |language=en-GB |work=The Guardian |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/aug/30/gabon-coup-military-takeover-gabonese-election-disputed |access-date=2023-08-30 |issn=0261-3077 |archive-date=30 August 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230830080603/https://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/aug/30/gabon-coup-military-takeover-gabonese-election-disputed |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text:
{{Expand section|date=August 2023}}
After Ali Bongo Ondimba's election victory was announced, a military-led coup took place, which annulled the results of the election.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite news |date=2023-08-30 |title=Gabon military officers declare coup after Ali Bongo wins disputed election |language=en-GB |work=The Guardian |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/aug/30/gabon-coup-military-takeover-gabonese-election-disputed |access-date=2023-08-30 |issn=0261-3077 |archive-date=30 August 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230830080603/https://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/aug/30/gabon-coup-military-takeover-gabonese-election-disputed |url-status=live }}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-08-30 |title=Gabon Military Officers Declare Coup |url=https://www.voanews.com/a/gabon-military-officers-declare-coup-/7246936.html |access-date=2023-08-30 |website=VOA |language=en |archive-date=30 August 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230830082626/https://www.voanews.com/a/gabon-military-officers-declare-coup-/7246936.html |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text: The coup occurred just minutes after Bongo's re-election was declared at 3:30 am West Africa Time|WAT by the Gabonese electoral commission with 64.27% of the vote. During a televised morning address from the Palais du bord de mer|Presidential Palace in Libreville on the state channel Gabon 24, around a dozen military personnel announced the end of the existing regime, with a military spokesperson claiming to be speaking on behalf of a "Committee for the Transition and Restoration of Institutions," citing "irresponsible, unpredictable governance" that had led to "a continuous degradation of social cohesion, risking pushing the country into chaos." and the closure of the country's borders. Internet access, which had been cut since the election, was reported to have been restored. Among the officers seen during the announcement were Gabonese Army|army colonels and members of the Gabonese Republican Guard|Republican Guard.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |last=Diekhans |first=Antje |title=Nach Präsidentschaftswahl: Militär stürzt Regierung in Gabun |url=https://www.tagesschau.de/ausland/afrika/gabun-militaer-104.html |access-date=30 August 2023 |website=tagesschau |language=de |archive-date=30 August 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230830110620/https://www.tagesschau.de/ausland/afrika/gabun-militaer-104.html |url-status=live }}</ref>
